thread.title: From a Balloon, a Different View of the Serengeti
thread.title_full: From a Balloon, a Different View of the Serengeti - The New York Times

author: M.j. Smith
title: From a Balloon, a Different View of the Serengeti
text:
KOTAGENDE, Tanzania — The website described a hot-air balloon flight over the Serengeti, and I saw zebras racing along below and a small family of elephants, so close that if the bull had stretched up his trunk, he could have touched the passenger basket.
But I must have imagined the whole thing because a few weeks later, home from the trip, I tried to find the video — and it just wasn’t there.
What I did have now were memories, even more vivid: A hippo, mostly submerged in the dark waters of the Serengeti’s Mara River, taking offense as the balloon’s large basket came lower and lower, finally settling what seemed to be just a few feet off the surface. She raised most of her large gray head, quickly opened her jaws wide and then, as if thinking better of the effort, sank back beneath the water.
It was only a minute or so, but it made up for the 3 a.m. wakeup call, the chilly flashlit walk across camp and the almost two-hour ride over the washed-out crossings and scarred surfaces that pass for roads in the Serengeti. (All right, seeing two lionesses suddenly appear alongside the Toyota Land Cruiser had helped a bit, too.)
We arrived around 6 at the launch site, where a handful of guys in orange jumpsuits or worn work clothes were pointing a high-powered fan into one of the two balloons going up that day. The nylon blob, what enthusiasts call the envelope, was stretched across the dry grass, shifting and billowing as it filled with air.
Once we were aloft, the sun was a streak of pink on the horizon. But within 20 minutes, it became too bright to see clearly, so I turned to focus on the river and the vast vista of the Serengeti, its straw-colored grasses already tinted with a light green after two days of sunset rain.
More hippo eyes visible just above the water’s surface; a couple of large crocodiles, inert on the banks. A few Thomson’s gazelles wandering nearby. And in a small bare patch, a lone wildebeest looking up at the balloon.
The day before I’d seen a column of wildebeest race toward the far bank and throw themselves into the water, a couple of thousand animals following the leader of the moment across the river to a new grazing area, a favorite tourist feature of the seasonal migration. They all made it across, but another tourist said an even larger group that crossed later in the day hadn’t been so lucky. The crocodiles had been waiting.
As we floated over the spot, some of the carcasses were stuck among the river boulders.
I never expected that, not even in my imaginary video.
